title: Mark Bartholomeusz
text:
Mark Bartholomeusz (born 30 June 1977) is a retired <a href="Australia">Australia</a>n professional <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> footballer. He played in the positions of fullback, flyhalf, inside centre, and wing.
Career.
Bartholomeusz attended <a href="Brisbane%20State%20High%20School">Brisbane State High School</a>.He played in the 1st XV from grade 10 in the same team as his older brother Greg. He was also a talented cricketer. He played for the <a href="Brumbies%20%28rugby%29">ACT Brumbies</a> and was a member of the side that defeated the Sharks in 2001 and the Crusaders in 2004 to win <a href="Super%2012">Super 12</a> titles.
He joined <a href="Saracens%20F.C.">Saracens</a> where he played the 2004–05 and 2005–06 seasons in the English Premiership, followed by Irish Magners League club <a href="Ulster%20Rugby">Ulster</a> for 2006–07 and 2007–08. In 2008, Bartholomeusz signed with <a href="Petrarca%20Rugby">Padova</a> to play in the Italian Super 10 (now <a href="Top12">Top12</a>) for the 2008/09 season. He returned to Australia to play for the <a href="Western%20Force">Western Force</a> in 2010 and 2011.
Bartholomeusz holds a record for having the fourth-shortest international rugby union career. In 2002, he represented <a href="Australia%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Australia</a> for 2 minutes and 33 seconds against <a href="Italy%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">Italy</a>. Nick Henderson (Australia), Sean McCahill (Ireland) and Mathieu Dourthe (France) are the only players to have shorter international careers.
